senses.de: How liked or well-known somebody or something is.
senses.ex: The popularity of the restaurant has increased since the new chef started.

Tips.title: Temporal Trend
Tips.description: Popularity can change over time, often rapidly due to trends or events.
Tips.example: The popularity of the fidget spinner faded as quickly as it rose.

Tips.title: Subjective Measure
Tips.description: Popularity is subjective and can vary among different groups or demographics.
Tips.example: In high school, popularity often depends on a student's social group.

Tips.title: Not Always Positive
Tips.description: Popularity does not always imply positive approval; it can be due to notoriety.
Tips.example: Despite its unpopularity among critics, the film was popular for its controversial theme.

Acclaim.wordDefinition:
Acclaim refers to the public recognition and praise given to someone or something for their achievements or qualities.

It is usually associated with critical success rather than popularity. For example, a book can receive critical acclaim from literary experts for its writing style and storytelling, but may not be widely popular among the general public.

Popularity is often based on the entertainment value, relatability or cultural significance of something. For example, a viral video may have tremendous popularity because it is appealing to a wide audience, but it may not necessarily receive critical acclaim.

Acclaim is recognition for excellence while popularity is the extent to which something or someone is liked by a large audience.

Admiration.wordDefinition:
Admiration means to have respect and approval for someone or something based on their qualities, achievements, or abilities.

It is applicable to describe feelings of respect or admiration for a person's character or accomplishments.

In simpler terms, admiration refers to a feeling of respect for someone or something, while popularity refers to the extent of how liked or well-known something or someone is.

Esteem.wordDefinition:
Esteem refers to the respect and admiration that someone has for themselves or that other people have for them based on their qualities and abilities.

In simple words, while esteem is about the level of respect and admiration for a person's qualities, popularity is about how well-known and liked that person is by others.

Fame.wordDefinition:
Fame refers to being widely recognized and respected for a particular achievement or talent. It usually involves a long-lasting reputation that extends beyond just one specific event or moment.

Both fame and popularity can occur in a variety of fields, such as entertainment, sports, politics, or social media.

However, fame is more focused on a long-standing reputation, while popularity tends to be more fleeting and based on current trends.

Glory.wordDefinition:
Glory refers to the admiration and respect earned by achieving something great or doing something heroic.

Glory is more about earning respect and recognition for exceptional accomplishments, while popularity is more about being well-liked and accepted by a lot of people.

Notoriety.wordDefinition:
Notoriety refers to being well-known for something negative or infamous, while popularity refers to being well-liked and well-known for positive reasons.

Notoriety is applicable when someone is known for actions or behaviors that are considered bad or unscrupulous, while popularity is applicable when someone has a likable personality, is talented, or has done something admirable.

For example, a celebrity who is notorious for drug use would have notoriety, while a celebrity who is popular for their acting skills would have popularity.

Renown.wordDefinition:
Renown refers to being widely recognized and respected for one's accomplishments or qualities over a longer period of time.

For example, a renowned scientist may be recognized and respected in their field for decades due to their contributions to research.

Both words describe a level of recognition, but popularity tends to be more fleeting and based on current trends, while renown is more long-lasting and based on sustained achievement.

Popularity is more applicable to the entertainment industry or trends in popular culture, while renown is more applicable to fields such as science, literature, or politics.

Reputation.wordDefinition:
Reputation is a more long-term and deeper concept. It refers to what people think of someone or something based on their actions, character, and behavior over time.

Reputation is earned and cannot be easily changed or manipulated. For example, a doctor might have a good reputation because they are knowledgeable and caring towards their patients.

Popularity is based on immediate reactions and can change quickly, while reputation is built over time and is more meaningful and permanent.

Popularity is applicable in situations where people's opinions are influenced by surface-level qualities, while reputation is applicable in situations where people's opinions are influenced by a person or organization's character and behavior over time.

quotes.Text: Russian strategy seems to center on maintaining Putin's popularity at home; building a strong military capacity in special forces, nuclear weapons, and advanced submarines; pressuring nearby nations to join various defense and customs pacts dominated by Russia; and pushing back on the U.S. wherever convenient.
quotes.Title: American Educator
quotes.Name: James G. Stavridis

quotes.Text: Top Gear''s popularity is a complete mystery to me. Maybe it's because it's still a car programme, but it's turned into a distorted world view from three men; a world view through the windscreen.
quotes.Title: English Journalist
quotes.Name: James May

quotes.Text: My guess is that people look at me and project their own values - importance of family, ego is healthy but not the biggest thing. I don't know. I can't explain my popularity.
quotes.Title: American Journalist
quotes.Name: Jane Pauley

quotes.Text: If you're holding out for universal popularity, I'm afraid you will be in this cabin for a very long time.
quotes.Title: English Author
quotes.Name: J. K. Rowling

quotes.Text: The greatest trap in our life is not success, popularity or power, but self-rejection.
quotes.Title: Dutch Clergyman
quotes.Name: Henri Nouwen

quotes.Text: True popularity comes from acts of kindness rather than acts of stupidity.
quotes.Title: American Businessman
quotes.Name: Bo Bennett

quotes.Text: There's no denying that my popularity helped me a lot.
quotes.Title: Indian Actress
quotes.Name: Amala Akkineni

quotes.Text: I'm not prepared to give up the truth for popularity.
quotes.Title: Israeli Politician
quotes.Name: Naftali Bennett

quotes.Text: I try not to be influenced by success or popularity.
quotes.Title: South Korean Rapper
quotes.Name: Suga

quotes.Text: Avoid popularity if you would have peace.
quotes.Title: American President
quotes.Name: Abraham Lincoln
